definition: Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord
pitchpipe, pitch standard, one of the twelve semitones in the traditional tone system
surname Lü
cloth/to declare/to announce/to spread/to make known
snake halberd

sentences.english: But Lyu Bu support at Mr. Cheng and Zhang Miao under, almost carried the old nest that the Cao holds.
sentences.chinese: 而呂布在程公和張邈的策應下，幾乎端了曹操的老巢。

sentences.english: With his excellent archery, Lü averted a fight between the two sides.
sentences.chinese: 就這樣，呂布以他精湛的箭法平息了一場廝殺。

sentences.english: So Lü invited both Liu Bei and Ji Ling to a bqnqet.
sentences.chinese: 於是，呂布讓人把劉備和紀靈同時請來赴宴。

sentences.english: Just then Lü Bu returned with a horse.
Zhang Jue had worsted Dong Zhuo and was following up his advantage.
sentences.chinese: 張撅了呂布和毛跟蹤他的優勢。

definition: Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
Han Xin (-196 BC), famous general of first Han emperor Liu Bang 劉邦|刘邦[Liu2 Bang1]

Diaochan (-192), one of the four legendary beauties 四大美女[si4 da4 mei3 nu:3], in fiction a famous beauty at the break-up of Han dynasty, given as concubine to usurping warlord Dong Zhuo 董卓[Dong3 Zhuo2] to ensure his overthrow by fighting hero Lü Bu 呂布|吕布[Lu:3 Bu4]

Guan Yu (-219), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, fearsome fighter famous for virtue and loyalty/posthumously worshipped and identified with the guardian Bodhisattva Sangharama

Zhuge Liang (181-234), military leader and prime minister of Shu Han 蜀漢|蜀汉 during the Three Kingdoms period/the main hero of the fictional Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义, where he is portrayed as a sage and military genius/mastermind
Zhang Fei (168-221), general of Shu and blood-brother of Liu Bei in Romance of the Three Kingdoms, famous as fearsome fighter and lover of wine
skilled manipulator/tactician/strategist/advisor/counsellor
Liu Bang (256 or 247-195 BC), bandit leader who became first Han emperor Han Gaozu 漢高祖|汉高祖 (reigned 202-195 BC)
Zhao Yun (-229), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Xiang Yu the Conqueror (232-202 BC), warlord defeated by first Han emperor

Di Renjie (607-700), Tang dynasty politician, prime minister under Wu Zetian, subsequently hero of legends/master sleuth Judge Dee, aka Chinese Sherlock Holmes, in novel Three murder cases solved by Judge Dee 狄公案[Di2 gong1 an4] translated by Dutch sinologist R.H. van Gulik 高羅珮|高罗佩[Gao1 Luo2 pei4]
a general or admiral
honey trap/sexual entrapment/CL:條|条[tiao2]
stratagem/scheme
Shu Han (c. 200-263), Liu Bei's kingdom in Sichuan during the Three Kingdoms, claiming legitimacy as successor of Han
Liu Chan 劉禪|刘禅 (207-271), son of Liu Bei, reigned as Shu Han emperor 233-263
